title: Species Accounts
text:
6 observations in 4 months across 4 sites. 13 total counted, high count 7. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor to the patch throughout the year. Mostly single birds, with a small flock on Balgove Bay on the 4th of May and a pair at the same site on the 17th of August. Perhaps surprising that I did not pick more birds up throughout the year, particularly during migration periods; I am unsure whether the birds seen on the patch this year come from the native population in the north-west, or introduced birds further south.

title: Species Accounts
text:
6 observations in 4 months across 4 sites. 13 total counted, high count 7. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor to the patch throughout the year. Mostly single birds, with a small flock on Balgove Bay on the 4th of May and a pair at the same site on the 17th of August. Perhaps surprising that I did not pick more birds up throughout the year, particularly during migration periods; I am unsure whether the birds seen on the patch this year come from the native population in the north-west, or introduced birds further south.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Pink-footed Goose
114 observations in 8 months across 27 sites. 12900 total counted, high count 1406. Breeding codes: none.























Common winter migrant and passage visitor. Most abundant during migration, particularly the southward autumn migration period from September to November, but also present throughout winter and spring. Last spring record on the 11th of April at North Haugh Pond, first autumn record on the 24th of September at the same location. Found throughout the patch, typically as flyover flocks. Often roosts on the Eden Estuary, and birds sometimes feed and roost in the field south and west of town.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Brant
39 observations in 11 months across 3 sites. 583 total counted, high count 44. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon winter migrant, with a few out-of-season records. Last spring record on the 4th of May, first autumn record on the 29th of September, with summer records on the 17th of June and 27th of August. Nearly exclusively found in Balgove Bay, with one record at the Aquarium on the 7th of December. The Balgove Bay flock reached a peak size of 44 birds (on the 30th of March), nearly all birds being of the pale-bellied hrota subspecies, with one dark-bellied bernicla bird seen every now and then.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Barnacle Goose
9 observations in 4 months across 4 sites. 281 total counted, high count 132. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon passage visitor, with one out-of-season record. First record in the autumn passage on the 26th of September at the Aquarium, with further records throughout the following couple of months until the final record at Out Head on the 10th of November. One summer record of 2 birds at Balgove Bay on the 19th of May. Most records involved flyover flocks of a couple dozen birds at a time, with birds typically coming in off the North Sea.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Canada Goose
13 observations in 4 months across 9 sites. 234 total counted, high count 56. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon passage visitor, with one out-of-season record. First record in the autumn passage on the 13th of August at home, with further records throughout the following few months until the final record at the Aquarium on the 5th of November. One summer (or early passage) record of 18 birds over North Haugh Pond on the 5th of June. Most records involved flyover flocks of a few dozen birds at a time at various locations around town.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Mute Swan
24 observations in 8 months across 4 sites. 57 total counted, high count 21. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon visitor to the patch throughout the year. Records typically involving single birds, with a couple of flocks seen on the Eden Estuary from Out Head, peaking at 21 birds on the 15th of June. Occurrence generally sporadic, with the exception of a lone immature bird which arrived at North Haugh Pond on the 29th of November and remained through to the end of the year.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Whooper Swan
7 observations in 4 months across 4 sites. 75 total counted, high count 21. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon passage visitor, mostly during late autumn. Only one record during the northward spring migration, with a flock of 4 birds seen distantly off the Aquarium on the 3rd of March; half a dozen records during the autumn migration, beginning on the 13th of October at Balgove Bay and culminating on the 24th of December at the same location. Most records pertaining to small flocks (less than two dozen birds) either flying over town or resting on the Eden Estuary.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Shelduck
63 observations in 12 months across 7 sites. 2701 total counted, high count 284. Breeding codes: FL.























Common resident, mostly localised to the Eden Estuary. Numbers varied throughout the year, with the highest counts at Balgove Bay during late winter and early autumn, peaking at 284 birds on the 17th of February. Bred nearby, if not on the patch, with a few chicks seen on the 17th of June. Outside of the Eden Estuary, a couple of records of birds flying past St Andrews Bay, probably on their way to or from the Estuary.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Wigeon
40 observations in 9 months across 5 sites. 2475 total counted, high count 234. Breeding codes: none.























Common winter migrant, mostly localised to the Eden Estuary. Last record for the spring on the 19th of May, and the first record for the autumn on the 28th of September. Peak numbers during the coldest months of the year in Balgove Bay, with a high count of 234 on the 14th of December. Outside of the Eden Estuary, a few records of birds in St Andrews Bay off the Aquarium, and a pair at North Haugh Pond on the 20th of November during a cold snap.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Mallard
367 observations in 12 months across 22 sites. 4839 total counted, high count 73. Breeding codes: FL.























One of the most widespread birds on the patch, found near just about any water source, as well as being often seen flying over town. Most abundant along the Lade Braes, particularly in the stretch between Dempster Terrace and Greenside Place, where 73 were counted on the 21st of January. Another flock of up to 50 birds inhabits North Haugh Pond, and there is presumably a significant amount of movement between sites around and beyond the patch. Most birds in town seem to be truly wild, but a small number of dumped domestic birds are also present in the main Lade Braes flock. Bred on the patch, with chicks seen at North Haugh Pond, Lade Braes, and Hepburn Gardens.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Northern Pintail
30 observations in 8 months across 2 sites. 890 total counted, high count 100. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon winter migrant, localised to the Eden Estuary (mostly in Balgove Bay). Last record for the spring on the 21st of April, and the first record for the autumn on the 28th of September. Typical flock size in both winter periods around 50 birds, with a high count of 100 on the 27th of November.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Green-winged Teal
30 observations in 10 months across 4 sites. 142 total counted, high count 30. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon visitor, with records concentrated during the autumn passage season. Most reliably encountered on Balgove Bay, but even there less common than in the inner Eden Estuary at Guardbridge or Coble Shore. Most records of single birds or small flocks of less than half a dozen birds, with a high count of 30 birds on the 13th of January and again on the 27th of August. Sporadically turns up at North Haugh Pond, where a handful of birds lingered from the 29th of September through til mid November. Odd records at the Aquarium, and could probably turn up elsewhere in St Andrews Bay, or indeed anywhere on the patch with open water.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Tufted Duck
17 observations in 7 months across 5 sites. 40 total counted, high count 5. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor, with records mostly in spring. Most records on North Haugh Pond, with as many as 5 birds lingering between the 22nd of February and the 3rd of June. A handful of other records in St Andrews Bay (off both the Aquarium and The Scores) and on the Eden Estuary (Balgove Bay and Out Head).

title: Species Accounts
text:
Greater Scaup
18 observations in 7 months across 4 sites. 233 total counted, high count 42. Breeding codes: none.























Rare winter migrant. Much more abundant in the first winter period than the second (a common pattern across most sea duck species this year). Last record for the spring on the 22nd of April at Out Head, and the first record for the autumn on the 28th of Septmber on Balgove Bay. Most common in St Andrews Bay, especially off the Aquarium, with the a couple of records on the Eden Estuary. The highest count was of 42 birds off the Aquarium on the 20th of January.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Eider
224 observations in 12 months across 9 sites. 7714 total counted, high count 377. Breeding codes: FL, N, P, H.























Common resident. Exclusively found along the coast from Balgove Bay all the way to Maiden Rock, mostly fairly close inshore. Flock sizes varied throughout the year, with the largest count on the 15th of August, a post-breeding flock on the Eden Estuary at Out Head. Birds bred on the patch, with chicks seen at Balgove Bay, the Aquarium, and The Scores.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Velvet Scoter
35 observations in 6 months across 4 sites. 233 total counted, high count 41. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon winter visitor. Exclusively found in St Andrews Bay, from West Sands to East Sands, with the majority of records off the Aquarium. As with a number of other sea ducks, more abundant in the first winter period than the second; the high count for the year was of 41 birds off the Aquarium on the 6th of January (the high count in the second winter period was only 18 birds, on the 16th of November). Last record for the spring on the 17th of March, and the first record for the autumn on the 8th of October.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Scoter
147 observations in 12 months across 9 sites. 21779 total counted, high count 1880. Breeding codes: none.























Common resident. Exclusively found along the coast from Balgove Bay all the way to Maiden Rock, with most records and the largest flocks off the Aquarium. Although reliably present throughout the year, more abundant in the first winter period than the second (as with several other sea duck species), with much smaller flock sizes during the summer. The highest count was of 1880 birds on the 7th of January, with the highest count during the second winter period only 600 (on the 26th of November). Although present year-round, birds do not breed locally (with summer records presumably referring to non-breeding birds that did not return to their more northerly breeding sites).

title: Species Accounts
text:
Long-tailed Duck
96 observations in 9 months across 8 sites. 1114 total counted, high count 162. Breeding codes: none.























Common winter migrant. Exclusively found along the coast from Balgove Bay all the way to Maiden Rock, but most frequent in the western half of St Andrews Bay from Out Head to the Aquarium. Although commonly seen throughout all the cooler months of the year, much more abundant in the first winter period than the second; the highest count was of 162 birds off the Aquarium on the 13th of January (the highest count in the second winter period was only 45 birds, at Out Head on the 10th of November). Last record for the spring on the 19th of May at Out Head, and the first autumn record on the 29th of September at Balgove Bay.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Goldeneye
22 observations in 6 months across 5 sites. 77 total counted, high count 22. Breeding codes: none.























Rare winter visitor, with a couple out-of-season records. Exclusively marine, with most records either in the outer Eden Estuary or on St Andrews Bay. Last seen in the first winter period on the 24th of February, and first seen in the second winter period on the 2nd of November. Two out of season records: a flock of 22 birds (the highest count of the year) at Out Head on the 6th of May, and a smaller flock of 5 at the same location on the 21st of July.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Merganser
25 observations in 10 months across 7 sites. 80 total counted, high count 14. Breeding codes: FL.























Uncommon visitor, with records concentrated during the autumn post-breeding season. Mostly marine, with the majority of records on the Eden Estuary or inshore in St Andrews Bay (the only exception being a flyover bird over North Haugh Pond on the 2nd of November). First seen on the 13th of January at Balgove Bay, but most records from July to September, with a high count of 14 birds on the 6th of July at Balgove Bay. Bred somewhere nearby (probably further upstream on the River Eden), with a few chicks seen at Out Head on the 15th of June.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Red-breasted Merganser
100 observations in 12 months across 8 sites. 478 total counted, high count 50. Breeding codes: none.























Common resident, more abundant during winter than summer. Exclusively found along the coast from Balgove Bay all the way to Maiden Rock, and particularly common in the outer Eden Estuary and inshore in St Andrews Bay. Most abundant in autumn, with several flocks of more than a dozen birds recorded between August and November, the largest a flock of 50 at Out Head on the 10th of November.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Gray Partridge
22 observations in 11 months across 6 sites. 62 total counted, high count 5. Breeding codes: P, S.























Rare resident. Found in several parts of the patch, with the total population size perhaps up to half a dozen family groups. At least one group (maybe more) inhabits St Andrews Links, another the field up behind North Haugh Pond, and a few more the fields south of town. Only ever seen in small family groups of up to 5 birds at once. Presumably bred locally, but no definitive observations (e.g. sightings of chicks) this year.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Ring-necked Pheasant
162 observations in 12 months across 12 sites. 332 total counted, high count 18. Breeding codes: none.























Common resident. Found in farmland all around the patch, with probably a mix of genuinely established feral birds and released/semi-tame birds (a few records of all-white domestic type birds support this theory). Records concentrated in and around the Balgove estate, especially around North Haugh Pond. More often recorded in spring, probably due to a combination of release timing and breeding season calling behaviour (although no definitive breeding behaviours observed). Generally recorded as single birds or small groups, with the high count of 18 birds (plus one all-white domestic type) in the field between the Strathkinness High and Low Roads on the 13th of January.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Rock Pigeon
461 observations in 12 months across 35 sites. 4675 total counted, high count 151. Breeding codes: N.























Common resident. Found all around the patch, although generally more abundant in urban parts than in rural or natural habitat. Particularly favours the cliffs and ruins along The Scores), where birds probably bred, although no direct evidence of this was observed. Generally seen in flocks of between 5 and 50 birds, with a high count of 151 on the 9th of January at North Haugh Pond.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Stock Dove
154 observations in 12 months across 17 sites. 295 total counted, high count 8. Breeding codes: N, C, P.























Common resident. Less frequently observed during the winter months, but this is presumably due to changes in behaviour and detectability, rather than any exodus of birds locally. Found mainly in the rural parts of the patch, particularly in the vicinity of the Balgove estate (including North Haugh Pond and St Andrews Links). Generally seen as single birds or pairs, with a couple of small flocks (the largest being of 8 birds, at North Haugh Pond on the 22nd of October and Balgove Farm on the 27th of December). A few records of pre-breeding behaviours including display and nest prospecting, but no definitive evidence of breeding (although presumably it did occur).

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Wood-Pigeon
842 observations in 12 months across 46 sites. 16129 total counted, high count 406. Breeding codes: none.























Common resident. Probably the most abundant resident species on the patch, easily observed no matter the location. Often seen in flocks of up to 100 birds at a time, with higher counts in the hundreds not particularly rare; the high count of 406 birds was a flock in the fields between Swilken Burn and Balgove Bay on the 21st of April. Rather surprisingly, no breeding behaviours observed, but birds almost certainly bred locally.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Collared-Dove
61 observations in 12 months across 15 sites. 110 total counted, high count 6. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon resident. Probably the rarest of the four pigeons on the patch, although still relatively common in the suburban parts of town, especially south of the Lade Braes. Typically seen as singles or small flocks of up to half a dozen birds. No breeding behaviours observed, but birds probably breed locally on rooftops and eaves in the more urban parts of the patch.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Swift
121 observations in 4 months across 30 sites. 601 total counted, high count 53. Breeding codes: none.























Common summer migrant. One of the last migrants to arrive in the spring, with the first record this year on the 10th of May at North Haugh Pond; similarly early to leave in the autumn, with the last record for the year on the 28th of August on Saint Leonard’s Road. Commonly seen flying overhead all throughout the patch, either as individuals or in flocks of up to several dozen birds at a time; the highest count for the year was of 53 birds over North Haugh Pond on the 20th of July. No breeding behaviours observed, although probably bred on the patch somewhere.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Water Rail
1 observations in 1 months across 1 sites. 1 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Only one record, at the start of the year - a bird calling in the reeds by Swilken Burn near North Haugh Pond on the 6th of January during a cold period. Probably underreported due to its cryptic nature, although given the scarcity of suitable habitat on the patch it is unlikely to be regular at any site locally.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Moorhen
205 observations in 12 months across 7 sites. 573 total counted, high count 13. Breeding codes: FL.























Common resident. Regular on all the bodies of freshwater across the patch, with most of my records coming from North Haugh Pond (including the smaller pond up near Madras College) and along the Lade Braes. Not abundant at any site, with generally no more than one or two pairs on a single water body; the highest count for the year was of 13 birds at North Haugh Pond on the 1st of July, although the majority of these were young birds. Numerous breeding records at several sites around the patch.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Coot
35 observations in 5 months across 1 sites. 49 total counted, high count 4. Breeding codes: FL.























Rare summer visitor. A perplexing species, entirely absent (despite seemingly suitable habitat and climate conditions) for the first half of the year, before a bird turned up unexpectedly at North Haugh Pond on the 3rd of June. A second bird arrived on the 14th of June, and by the start of August they had bred on the pond, with two chicks seen with the adults on the 2nd of August. Sightings continued on the pond until the 3rd of October, after which they disappeared completely. It is unclear whether this seasonal breeding occurrence happens each year, or whether this was an isolated case unlikely to be repeated again any time soon.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Oystercatcher
430 observations in 12 months across 34 sites. 41258 total counted, high count 2500. Breeding codes: A, N.























Common resident. Abundant on the Eden Estuary, with counts in the thousands not unusual at Balgove Bay (where a high count of 2500 birds was recorded on the 27th of November). Also common all along the coast, although typically in smaller flocks of up to 100 birds rather than the thousands present on the Estuary. No confirmed breeding records on the patch, although birds were present year-round despite a drop-off in numbers through the spring and summer.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Black-bellied Plover
22 observations in 9 months across 2 sites. 350 total counted, high count 49. Breeding codes: none.























Rare winter visitor. Exclusively found on the Eden Estuary, with records at both Balgove Bay and Out Head. Last record for the spring on the 21st of April at Balgove Bay, with the first autumn record on the 15th of August at Out Head. Generally seen in small flocks of up to a dozen birds, with a couple of larger counts recorded, peaking at 49 on the 3rd of March.

title: Species Accounts
text:
European Golden-Plover
8 observations in 4 months across 4 sites. 56 total counted, high count 24. Breeding codes: none.























Rare passage visitor. Most records on the Eden Estuary, particularly Balgove Bay, with a couple of flyover flocks elsewhere in town during the autumn passage. Only one record during the spring passage, an early bird at Balgove Bay on the 24th of February. More regular during autumn, although still scarce, with a couple of singles on the Estuary during early autumn and flocks of up to two dozen birds in October and November (with the high count recorded on the 31st of October near Rufflets).

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Ringed Plover
29 observations in 11 months across 4 sites. 592 total counted, high count 170. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon resident. Mostly restricted to the Eden Estuary, particularly the rockier north-east shore of Balgove Bay, with a couple of records along the coast too. More records during the second half of the year, but recorded in all months except for March, despite not breeding locally. Generally seen in fairly small numbers, with occasional large flocks forming on Balgove Bay; the largest of these was 170 birds on the 24th of August.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Northern Lapwing
27 observations in 8 months across 9 sites. 1227 total counted, high count 300. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon passage migrant. Despite occurring in the general region throughout the year, most records on the patch were during the extended autumn passage from June through November. Generally confined to the Eden Estuary (both Balgove Bay and Out Head), with a couple of records on fields in the north-west part of town and flyover sightings elsewhere. Numbers peaked during mid October, with a high count of 300 birds at Balgove Bay on the 19th of October.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Whimbrel
9 observations in 3 months across 2 sites. 13 total counted, high count 4. Breeding codes: none.























Rare passage migrant. Surprisingly scarce on the patch, despite plenty of suitable habitat on the Eden Estuary. Records during both the spring and autumn passage seasons, although slightly more abundant during autumn. In the spring, first recorded on the 14th of April and last on the 11th of May, with all records on Balgove Bay. In the autumn, first recorded on the 1st of August and last on the 27th, with a high count of four birds on the 17th.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Curlew
200 observations in 12 months across 27 sites. 14438 total counted, high count 678. Breeding codes: none.























Common resident. One of the most common waders on the patch; abundant on the Eden Estuary but also present along the coastline and on fields and farmland on the outskirts of town. Less abundant during spring and summer, when most birds leave the patch to breed (with only non-breeders remaining), but still recorded in good numbers throughout the year. Most abundant during winter, with a high count of 678 birds observed on the 18th of February on Balgove Bay.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Bar-tailed Godwit
37 observations in 11 months across 3 sites. 1083 total counted, high count 411. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon winter visitor. Although recorded in all but one month of the year (missing in June, alongside several other waders), probably best described as a winter visitor to the patch given the increased numbers throughout the colder months of the year. Flocks of more than 100 birds were observed at Balgove Bay and Out Head during January, February, and December, with a high count of 411 birds on the 20th of December at Out Head.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Black-tailed Godwit
1 observations in 1 months across 1 sites. 11 total counted, high count 11. Breeding codes: none.























Rare passage visitor. Despite the relative regularity of its Bar-tailed cousin on the patch, this species was recorded just once this year, a flock of 11 birds flying past Balgove Bay on the 6th of April. This is made even more perplexing by the frequency with which birds are recorded further upstream on the Eden Estuary at Guardbridge - perhaps this disparity is reflective of my bad luck, or perhaps it reflects a real microhabitat preference displayed by this species in the area?

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Woodcock
1 observations in 1 months across 1 sites. 1 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Probably underrecorded given its cryptic nature, but only one record this year, a bird flushed from under a pine tree at North Haugh Pond on the 22nd of January.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Snipe
5 observations in 5 months across 2 sites. 6 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: none.























Rare winter visitor. Probably more regular than records suggest, especially during cold snaps when birds are displaced from their regular haunts as they freeze over. A couple of records around North Haugh Pond (on the 8th of February and 8th of December), with the remainder at Balgove Bay.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Red Phalarope
1 observations in 1 months across 1 sites. 1 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. One of the best birds of the year, and a very unexpected record - a single bird on Balgove Bay late in the evening of the 27th of August. May well have occurred offshore later in the autumn, as is more typical for this species in Scotland, although the relative lack of storms (in comparison with 2023) meant that I did not pick any birds up.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Sandpiper
5 observations in 2 months across 2 sites. 7 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: none.























Rare passage visitor. Only present on the patch for a couple of weeks between late July and early August, with my first record on the 23rd of July and my last on the 1st of August. All records between the Aquarium and The Scores, although could plausibly occur in suitable habitat elsewhere on the patch (such as the East Sands Harbour or further along the Coastal Path).

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Redshank
165 observations in 11 months across 11 sites. 4322 total counted, high count 600. Breeding codes: none.























Common winter visitor. Although recorded in almost all months of the year (May being the only blank month), probably better described as a winter migrant given the dramatic increase in numbers on the patch throughout the colder half of the year. Mostly restricted to the coastline between Balgove Bay and the Coastal Path, with a couple of records around North Haugh Pond during wet periods when the meadow turns into a mire. Most abundant on the Eden Estuary, with a high count of 600 birds at Balgove Bay on the 27th of November.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Lesser Yellowlegs
4 observations in 2 months across 1 sites. 4 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. The best bird of the year - a first record for the patch and just the second record for Fife. Found in the evening of the 24th of July on the rocks at The Scores, and lingered at the same site for several weeks before disappearing in early August.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Greenshank
19 observations in 8 months across 7 sites. 23 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon winter visitor. Recorded all along the coast, from Balgove Bay to Maiden Rock, although not especially common in any one location (with the exception of a couple of lingering birds, for example in the roost along The Scores in November and December). Last recorded in spring on the 23rd of March along the Coastal Path, with the first autumn record on the 27th of August on Balgove Bay. Generally solitary, with a couple of records of two birds at several sites throughout the year.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Ruddy Turnstone
98 observations in 11 months across 9 sites. 2123 total counted, high count 277. Breeding codes: none.























Common winter visitor. Exclusively coastal, with records from Balgove Bay to Maiden Rock. Last recorded in the spring on the 5th of May, with the first record in the autumn on the 23rd of July. Most frequently recorded between the Aquarium and The Scores, particularly in the high tide roosts. Although less abundant than some of the other common species, large flocks of more than one hundred birds were noted on several occasions, with the highest count being 277 birds by the Aquarium on the 10th of February during a storm.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Red Knot
32 observations in 11 months across 4 sites. 2486 total counted, high count 700. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon winter visitor. Exclusively coastal, with most records from the Eden Estuary (both Balgove Bay and Out Head) and a couple of records further along the coast between the Aquarium and The Scores. Last spring record on the 4th of May, with the first autumn record on the 23rd of July. Most abundant on the Eden Estuary, where flocks of several hundred birds were noted on several occasions, including a high count of 700 on the 20th of January at Out Head.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Ruff
1 observations in 1 months across 1 sites. 1 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Although reliably recorded on the Eden Estuary during the autumn migration, just one record on the patch this year - a juvenile at Balgove Bay on the 28th of September. This is likely partly a result of missing most of September due to travel, and thus birds are probably more regular on the patch than the single record this year would suggest.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Sanderling
43 observations in 10 months across 4 sites. 1324 total counted, high count 120. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon winter visitor. Found along the coast from Balgove Bay to the Aquarium, with records throughout the colder months of the year. The last record in the spring was on the 6th of May at Out Head, with the first autumn record on the 17th of August at Balgove Bay. Not especially abundant, but a few records of a hundred birds or more noted, including a high count of 120 on the 7th of January at Out Head.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Dunlin
45 observations in 12 months across 5 sites. 8845 total counted, high count 1958. Breeding codes: none.























Common winter visitor. One of the most abundant waders on the patch during the winter months, with more than a thousand birds present on the Eden Estuary at times. Recorded in all months of the year, but most abundant between October and February (no counts of more than one hundred birds were recorded outside of these months). The highest count of the year was of 1958 birds, recorded on the 13th of January on Balgove Bay.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Purple Sandpiper
47 observations in 9 months across 7 sites. 357 total counted, high count 50. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon winter visitor. A real St Andrews specialty, with birds regularly occurring on the rocky shoreline between the Aquarium and The Scores from October through April (with a couple of out of season records also noted, and the odd bird elsewhere along the coast). Most abundant in the high tide roost at the Aquarium, with a high count of 50 birds on the 10th of February during a storm, and several other counts in excess of twenty birds recorded throughout the two winter periods.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Parasitic Jaeger
10 observations in 4 months across 2 sites. 30 total counted, high count 9. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon passage visitor. One of the most common pelagic seabirds recorded on the patch, but still rather scarce. Only recorded during the autumn passage season, with the first record on the 28th of July and the last record on the 9th of October. Generally seen in small numbers well offshore, with a high count of just nine birds off the Aquarium on the 1st of October.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Great Skua
1 observations in 1 months across 1 sites. 1 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Only a single record this year, with one bird flying past the Aquarium on the 1st of October. As with other pelagic seabirds, probably more regular offshore in St Andrews Bay, and more likely to occur during storms with strong offshore winds.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Atlantic Puffin
4 observations in 2 months across 2 sites. 6 total counted, high count 3. Breeding codes: none.























Rare winter visitor. Despite breeding just 25km away on the Isle of May, this species is paradoxically scarce in St Andrews Bay, with no records during the breeding season; birds seemingly avoid flying west into the Bay, opting to feed either further offshore or in the Firth of Forth. Nevertheless, several records in the latter months of the year, apparently part of a broader influx into the North Sea during this period. First recorded on the 26th of November off the Aquarium, with a high count of three birds off The Scores on the 14th of December and a final record on the 23rd of December also off the Aquarium.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Black Guillemot
1 observations in 1 months across 1 sites. 1 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Increasingly recorded in Fife in recent years, but still quite rare, and not at all regular in St Andrews Bay. Indeed, this was the final species added to the patch list for the year, with a single bird off the Aquarium on the 20th of December.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Razorbill
65 observations in 11 months across 7 sites. 764 total counted, high count 168. Breeding codes: FL.























Common resident. The most frequently encountered alcid on the patch, with records in all but one month of the year, and birds being generally fairly reliable offshore in St Andrews Bay, particularly during calm periods with flat seas. Recorded mostly from Out Head to Maiden Rock, with an unusual sighting in the Eden Estuary at Balgove Bay on the 4th of May. Most abundant during autumn, when flocks of dozens of birds were observed multiple times, including a high count of 168 off the Aquarium on the 23rd of July. Did not breed on the patch itself, but young chicks seen offshore with adults in late summer and early autumn.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Dovekie
3 observations in 2 months across 1 sites. 4 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Probably best described as a regular vagrant to the patch, with records generally coinciding with larger influxes of the species into the North Sea during winter storms. Three records this year, all in the second winter period and all off the Aquarium, with the first on the 16th of November and the last on the 21st of December.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Murre
57 observations in 12 months across 6 sites. 555 total counted, high count 120. Breeding codes: FL.























Common resident. The other regular alcid on the patch, with records in all months of the year. As with Razorbill, abundance peaked during late summer and early autumn, when post-breeding flocks with recently fledged chicks were present offshore; the high count for the year was of 120 birds on the 5th of July.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Little Gull
8 observations in 5 months across 3 sites. 99 total counted, high count 80. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Only sporadically present on the patch, with no clear seasonal pattern although probably most likely to occur during autumn migration. Seen along the coast from Out Head to The Scores, often in association with periods of strong onshore winds. Numbers generally low, with a notable high count of 80 birds in a flock off The Scores on the 26th of September.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Black-legged Kittiwake
62 observations in 11 months across 8 sites. 3485 total counted, high count 1900. Breeding codes: none.























Common summer visitor. Recorded on the patch in most months of the year, but much more abundant during summer and early autumn, with most winter records associated with storms. Exclusively coastal, with the majority of birds observed between Out Head and Maiden Rock (notwithstanding a couple of records in Balgove Bay). Although mostly observed in small numbers or flocks up to 50 birds in size, post-breeding flocks in late summer tended to be much larger, with an exceptional high count of 1900 birds off The Scores on the 26th of September.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Black-headed Gull
282 observations in 12 months across 27 sites. 9477 total counted, high count 1003. Breeding codes: none.























Common resident. Abundant throughout the majority of the year, although most birds disappeared during spring and early summer to breed inland. Most frequently encountered along the coast, but nevertheless common inland and throughout town. The highest count of the year was of 1003 birds on the beach at the Aquarium on the 7th of January, part of a larger gull flock of several thousand birds.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Gull
125 observations in 12 months across 12 sites. 5140 total counted, high count 2300. Breeding codes: none.























Common resident. Although present throughout the year, much more abundant during late winter and early spring, with flocks numbering in the hundreds recorded from January to April. Primarily marine and estuarine, but the odd bird or flock recorded inland at various locations, including several records around North Haugh Pond. As with Black-headed Gull, the highest count of the year was on the 7th of January, with 2300 birds at Out Head and more further down the beach along West Sands.

title: Species Accounts
text:
European Herring Gull
1051 observations in 12 months across 49 sites. 26495 total counted, high count 2700. Breeding codes: NY, FL, ON, CN, S.























Common resident. One of the most abundant and frequently recorded birds on the patch, ubiquitous throughout town and in all months of the year. The highest count was of 2700 birds on the 7th of January at Out Head (part of the massive gull flock on the beach that afternoon), with several further counts of more than 100 birds recorded throughout the year. Birds bred on the patch at several locations, favouring the roofs of buildings for their nests; young chicks were seen throughout town between June and July.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Great Black-backed Gull
188 observations in 12 months across 15 sites. 425 total counted, high count 7. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon resident. Frequently recorded all along the coast from Balgove Bay to Maiden Rock (with a handful of records at inland sites in addition), but never abundant, with a high count of just seven birds (noted three times throughout the year). Most reliable at the Aquarium, where one or two birds almost always present on the rocks, and others often seen out to sea. Did not breed on the patch, with the closest breeding birds probably on the Isle of May.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Lesser Black-backed Gull
191 observations in 10 months across 26 sites. 426 total counted, high count 13. Breeding codes: FL, ON.























Common summer migrant. Not quite as ubiquitous as Herring Gull, but nevertheless a familiar site during the warmer months of the year, and the other species of gull to breed on the patch (with similar habits to the former). First recorded on the 17th of February at the Aquarium, with the first evidence of breeding on the 1st of June and a final record for the year on the 10th of November at Out Head.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Iceland Gull
1 observations in 1 months across 1 sites. 1 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. One of the best finds of the year, with a single bird roosting in a gull flock off the Aquarium late in the evening of the 4th of November. Unfortunately a one-day wonder, but could (and should) plausibly occur again, likely as part of a larger gull flock during winter.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Arctic Tern
5 observations in 3 months across 3 sites. 22 total counted, high count 13. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon summer migrant. Surprisingly scarce on the patch this year, although perhaps in part due to the difficulties in identifying distant terns flying offshore (some of which will undoubtedly have been this species). First recorded on the 18th of June at the Aquarium, with further records over the next couple of months in St Andrews Bay and on the Eden Estuary until a final record on the 17th of August at Balgove Bay. Recorded both as single birds and in flocks, with the largest count comprising 13 birds off the Aquarium on the 13th of August.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Tern
10 observations in 2 months across 4 sites. 58 total counted, high count 18. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon summer migrant. As with Arctic Tern, remarkably scarce on the patch this year, and rather late to arrive. First recorded on the 11th of August off at the Aquarium, with records throughout August and September until a final sighting of 18 birds (the high count for the year) off The Scores on the 26th of September.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Sandwich Tern
54 observations in 6 months across 9 sites. 594 total counted, high count 88. Breeding codes: none.























Common summer migrant. Comfortably the most abundant tern on the patch, with records from Balgove Bay all the way to Maiden Rock, although somewhat sporadic in occurrence, being notably absent throughout the month of June. First recorded on the 13th of April near East Sands, with records through until a final in-season record on the 2nd of October off The Scores, followed by a very late bird passing the Aquarium a month later on the 7th of November. The highest count of 88 birds was recorded on the 31st of July, comprising a consistent passage of birds moving past The Scores.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Little Grebe
45 observations in 11 months across 4 sites. 54 total counted, high count 3. Breeding codes: FL, A, P, H.























Uncommon resident. Somewhat perplexing in its pattern of occurrence on the patch, birds do not seem to remain faithful to one site for any extended period of time, but rather move around extensively - perhaps in response to food availability or weather conditions. Recorded in most months of the year, but more frequently encountered in spring and summer, when a pair was present on North Haugh Pond between March and October; these birds bred on the pond, with the chick first seen on the 24th of May. Otherwise scarce, with a couple of autumn and winter records in St Andrews Bay, mostly near the Aquarium.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Horned Grebe
32 observations in 8 months across 4 sites. 61 total counted, high count 6. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon winter migrant. Regular but not abundant in the outer Eden Estuary throughout the colder months of the year, with occasional records in St Andrews Bay as well. Last recorded in the spring on the 21st of April at Balgove Bay, and first recorded in the autumn at the same site on the 29th of September. Generally only in small numbers, with a high count of just six birds (at Out Head on the 10th of November).

title: Species Accounts
text:
Red-necked Grebe
1 observations in 1 months across 1 sites. 1 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. One of the best birds on the patch this year, with a single bird picked out from nearby Great Crested Grebes on the sea off the Aquarium on the 26th of November. The bird did not linger unfortunately, but further birds could plausibly occur at any point during winter.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Great Crested Grebe
55 observations in 9 months across 6 sites. 209 total counted, high count 16. Breeding codes: none.























Common winter migrant. The most frequently encountered grebe on the patch, being a regular fixture in St Andrews Bay throughout the colder months of the year. Last seen in the spring on the 21st of April at Balgove Bay, and first recorded in the autumn on the 30th of September off The Scores, with a couple of summer records in late July perhaps comprising failed breeders. Mostly seen in loose flocks of about half a dozen birds offshore, with a high count of 16 birds recorded in early January off the Aquarium.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Red-throated Loon
83 observations in 12 months across 7 sites. 270 total counted, high count 39. Breeding codes: none.























Common resident. Exclusively marine, with records from Out Head to Maiden Rock. Although not a patch breeder, present throughout the year (with summer records presumably comprising young birds or failed breeders). More abundant during migration periods, when large flocks occasionally stage offshore in St Andrews Bay, the largest this year being 39 birds off Out Head on the 6th of May.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Loon
8 observations in 4 months across 3 sites. 10 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Seems to occur sporadically on the patch, although probably more regular during the colder months of the year, with most records between October and December. Records from Out Head to The Scores, although probably occurs further east in St Andrews Bay, and could also stage on the Eden Estuary too. Generally seen just as single birds, with a couple of records of two birds at a time.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Northern Fulmar
131 observations in 10 months across 10 sites. 7231 total counted, high count 434. Breeding codes: NY, ON, A, N, P.























Common resident. A true St Andrews specialty, with the largest colony of the species in Fife on the cliffs between the Aquarium and East Sands comprising approximately 200 breeding pairs. Present in the colony throughout the year with the exception of early autumn when birds disperse post-breeding, before returning in November (with the first returning birds seen on the 5th of November, and more than 100 birds back by the 26th).

title: Species Accounts
text:
Sooty Shearwater
1 observations in 1 months across 1 sites. 1 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Just one record of this species this year, a single individual past The Scores on the 26th of September during the peak seabird passage period. As with other scarce seabirds, probably more common offshore in St Andrews Bay, given how regular this species is past Fife Ness throughout the autumn.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Manx Shearwater
3 observations in 2 months across 2 sites. 8 total counted, high count 5. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon passage visitor. Only recorded three times during the autumn seabird passage, with birds seen flying past the Aquarium and The Scores in July and August. Probably more common further offshore, and could plausibly occur in higher numbers during periods of strong onshore winds.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Northern Gannet
103 observations in 11 months across 8 sites. 1690 total counted, high count 132. Breeding codes: none.























Common summer migrant. One of the most abundant seabirds offshore in St Andrews Bay during the summer months, with birds returning early in the spring and remaining in the region into late autumn. First recorded for the year on the 29th of February, with the final record on the 29th of December (both records coming from the Aquarium). Numbers peak in late summer and autumn following breeding, when both adults and juveniles pass through St Andrews Bay on their southward migration (the highest count for the year coming on the 31st of July at The Scores).

title: Species Accounts
text:
Great Cormorant
233 observations in 12 months across 14 sites. 2165 total counted, high count 115. Breeding codes: none.























Common resident. Ubiquitous along the coastline from Balgove Bay to Maiden Rock, with occasional records inland (mostly comprising flyover birds). Generally seen in small numbers roosting on the rocks or feeding offshore, but forms large flocks on the sandbars in the outer Eden Estuary, with the highest count this year being 115 birds at Balgove Bay on the 27th of August.

title: Species Accounts
text:
European Shag
5 observations in 4 months across 2 sites. 9 total counted, high count 4. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Despite breeding on the Isle of May just 25km away, and being common throughout much of the Fife coast, this species was very scarce in Fife this year, with just five records. Undoubtedly this is in large part due to the effects of the 2023-24 storm season, which saw the local population decimated; it will be interesting to see what happens to this species’ occurrence on the patch in coming years as the population rebounds. Most records this year comprised individual birds, with a high count of four seen at the Aquarium on the 20th of January.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Little Egret
36 observations in 11 months across 6 sites. 86 total counted, high count 12. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon visitor. A fairly regular sight on the Eden Estuary, with records in most months of the year and a high count of 12 birds at Balgove Bay on the 29th of September; most abundant during autumn, with all records of half a dozen or more birds falling between August and October. Occasionally encountered outside the estuary, with a couple of records along the coastline and several sightings around North Haugh Pond, mostly in the first couple of months of the year.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Gray Heron
296 observations in 12 months across 23 sites. 611 total counted, high count 13. Breeding codes: NB, N, P.























Common resident. Present throughout town wherever there is water (with additional records of flyovers elsewhere). Most frequently seen around North Haugh Pond and on the cliffs by the Aquarium; the highest count was at North Haugh Pond, with 13 birds observed on the 2nd of February. Birds bred on the patch in several locations, with nesting observed along the Lade Braes and at the back of North Haugh Pond.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Osprey
18 observations in 4 months across 6 sites. 21 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon summer migrant. Restricted on the patch to the outer Eden Estuary, with all records outside of Out Head and Balgove Bay comprising flyovers of birds headed towards the estuary. First recorded on the 6th of May at Out Head, with further records over the summer months until the final sighting on the 27th of August. Mostly only one bird seen at a time, with a few records of a pair together.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Sparrowhawk
66 observations in 12 months across 17 sites. 72 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: none.























Common resident. Seen throughout town, although mostly in the vicinity of North Haugh Pond, where a pair of birds were present throughout the year. More frequently encountered outside of summer, perhaps suggesting a change in the detectability of birds during the breeding season. No direct breeding evidence observed, although likely that birds did breed somewhere on the patch, perhaps in the woods behind the Balgove estate.

title: Species Accounts
text:
White-tailed Eagle
1 observations in 1 months across 1 sites. 1 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Seen only once, a single adult bird observed on the Eden Estuary at Balgove Bay on the 13th of January, presumably one of the reintroduced local birds that have been present in Fife for several years now.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Buzzard
185 observations in 12 months across 17 sites. 278 total counted, high count 5. Breeding codes: C.























Common resident. The most frequently encountered raptor on the patch, seen throughout the year and in most parts of town (although more common in the more wooded north-west and southern edge). No definitive evidence of breeding on the patch, but the continual presence of a pair of birds around North Haugh Pond throughout the year, and the juvenile bird seen several times near the pond during autumn would suggest that breeding did occur somewhere nearby, perhaps in the woods behind the Balgove estate.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Western Barn Owl
2 observations in 2 months across 2 sites. 2 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Almost certainly more regular on the patch than records suggest, but only observed twice - both records comprising individual birds out hunting on separate evenings. The first bird was seen hunting over stubble fields by the Strathkinness Low Road on the 23rd of October, while the second bird was on the field up behind North Haugh Pond on Christmas night.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Tawny Owl
8 observations in 5 months across 4 sites. 11 total counted, high count 4. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon resident. Probably several pairs throughout the patch, but only irregularly encountered given their nocturnal habits. Most records from near home, including four birds observed on the night of the 14th of November, likely comprising a family group of adults and young.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Short-eared Owl
5 observations in 2 months across 2 sites. 5 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Only seen in two months of the year, with several records during August likely due to the same bird hanging around the Eden Estuary for several weeks. All records from either Out Head or Balgove Bay, and all comprising just a single bird.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Kingfisher
19 observations in 8 months across 5 sites. 21 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: none.























Rare resident. A secretive inhabitant of aquatic habitats around town, with birds observed on North Haugh Pond, on the Kinness Burn by Lade Braes, and along the coastline from the Aquarium to Maiden Rock. Conspicuously absent throughout most of the summer, so perhaps did not breed locally, but may well have also just bred secretively somewhere on the patch. Usually just seen singly, with a couple of sightings of a pair at North Haugh Pond.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Great Spotted Woodpecker
56 observations in 12 months across 9 sites. 58 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon resident. Present throughout most of the woods around town, particularly in the north-west around the Balgove estate. No definitive breeding evidence, but almost certainly breeds locally given this species’ sedentary nature and the regularity of sightings throughout the year. Mostly seen singly, with a couple of sightings of two birds: on the 23rd of April along Lade Braes, and on the 5th of May by North Haugh Pond.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Kestrel
17 observations in 8 months across 5 sites. 17 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon visitor. Probably more common (and likely resident) just outside town, with several records on the outskirts of the patch in farmland, although birds not regular at any one site on the patch. Seen throughout the year, although only in eight months, and only ever one bird at a time.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Peregrine Falcon
12 observations in 7 months across 6 sites. 13 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: none.























Uncommon visitor. As with Eurasian Kestrel, not resident in town but probably bred somewhere nearby, given the relative regularity of sightings throughout the year. Several sightings on Balgove Bay, including a record of two birds on the 14th of December.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Jay
13 observations in 3 months across 2 sites. 20 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. It is difficult to say with certainty what this species’ status on the patch is, given the somewhat perplexing pattern of occurrence throughout the year. The majority of records of the species came from North Haugh Pond during autumn and winter, with two birds present around the pond from early October to the end of the year; the same pattern of occurrence in late 2023 at the pond suggests this may be a regular annual occurrence. In addition, two birds were seen in Lumbo Den on the 1st of June; given how infrequently I birded in these woods throughout the year they may be more regular there, but it is hard to say with certainty whether birds are resident in the patch or whether they just move through from time to time.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Magpie
385 observations in 12 months across 38 sites. 674 total counted, high count 10. Breeding codes: none.























Common resident. Present throughout the year and all across the patch, with birds being particularly abundant in parks, gardens and rural areas (mostly avoiding the most built up parts of town, as well as the Eden Estuary and St Andrews Bay). Generally seen in ones or twos, with occasional small flocks of up to 10 birds (the high count for the year coming on the 13th of January along Buchanan Gardens). Not seen breeding on the patch, but given its abundance and resident nature, almost certainly did.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Jackdaw
715 observations in 12 months across 41 sites. 5898 total counted, high count 219. Breeding codes: N, C.























Common resident. One of the most abundant birds on the patch; flocks of more than one hundred birds were observed at North Haugh Pond (on the 3rd of March and 28th of July), around the Balgove estate (on the 30th and 31st of March), and in Lumbo Den (on the 7th of July; this was the largest flock of the year, numbering 219 birds). Often seen in association with other corvids.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Rook
315 observations in 12 months across 34 sites. 1803 total counted, high count 111. Breeding codes: FL, ON, UN, CN, N.























Common resident. Although less abundant than Eurasian Jackdaw or Carrion Crow, nevertheless a common bird around town, with at least two active rookeries on the patch: one in the trees by Eden Clubhouse (on the golf course), and another in the trees around Mill Pond (along the Lade Braes). Often seen in flocks, with the largest flock of the year numbering 111 birds on West Sands on the 10th of February.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Carrion Crow
943 observations in 12 months across 45 sites. 6013 total counted, high count 161. Breeding codes: ON, CN, A, C.























Common resident. One of the most common birds in town, being seen in all parts of the patch and in all months of the year, often in large numbers. The largest flock of the year comprised 161 birds near Balgove Bay on the 29th of September; counts of more than 50 birds were also recorded at Out Head, the Aquarium, and West Sands. Birds bred in several locations around the patch, with nesting behaviours seen near David Russell Apartments, Doubledykes Road, the Observatory, North Haugh Pond, and the golf course.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Raven
9 observations in 3 months across 4 sites. 16 total counted, high count 3. Breeding codes: none.























Rare winter visitor. Present around North Haugh Pond during the first couple of months of the year, with up to three birds seen throughout January and February (the final record coming on the 18th of February); records at the Observatory and along Lade Braes during this period probably referred to the same birds wandering around town. Not seen again until November, when a pair of birds flew past the Aquarium on the 5th.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Coal Tit
251 observations in 12 months across 23 sites. 418 total counted, high count 7. Breeding codes: FL, C, S7, S.























Common resident. Although less abundant than Great or Blue Tits, nevertheless a common bird throughout the patch, particularly favouring stands of conifers such as those around North Haugh Pond or the Observatory. More frequently seen during the winter period, although unclear whether this is reflective of an influx of migrants from further afield, or changes in the detectability of local resident birds. Birds bred on the patch, with chicks seen at the Sports Centre on the 8th of June and at North Haugh Pond on the 1st of July. The high count of the year was of just seven birds, seen around North Haugh Pond on the 29th of September.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Blue Tit
607 observations in 12 months across 40 sites. 2163 total counted, high count 21. Breeding codes: FL, S.























Common resident. The most abundant tit on the patch, present all throughout town with the exception of most of the golf course and Out Head. Somewhat more frequently encountered during winter than summer, but this is probably mostly due to changes in detectability rather than movement of birds in or out of the patch. Birds bred on the patch, with chicks seen at North Haugh Pond on the 16th of June and in Lumbo Den on the 13th of July. The highest count of the year was of 21 birds, seen around North Haugh Pond on the 1st of February.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Great Tit
263 observations in 12 months across 28 sites. 494 total counted, high count 12. Breeding codes: CN, S7, S.























Common resident. Somewhat less abundant than Eurasian Blue Tit, but still commmon and widespread on the patch, and recorded regularly in all months of the year (although somewhat less frequently during summer). Birds bred on the patch, with nesting behaviour observed on the path between Swilken Burn and Balgove Bay on the 4th of May and singing birds heard in several other locations around the patch. The highest count for the year came on the 17th of February, when 12 birds were observed along the Lade Braes.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Skylark
215 observations in 12 months across 30 sites. 681 total counted, high count 31. Breeding codes: A, M, S7, S, H.























Common resident. A familiar sight in open habitats around town, and a distinctive breeder on the patch owing to its wonderful display flights given throughout spring and summer. Recorded mostly during the breeding season, with singing birds first heard on the 25th of March at North Haugh Pond and peak activity during May, when singing birds were observed all throughout town in suitable breeding habitat. Most birds stopped singing by the end of July, after which birds were seen quite regularly moving through town during the autumn passage (with a high count of 31 birds over North Haugh Pond on the 10th of October); a few birds remained on the patch through winter.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Sedge Warbler
24 observations in 4 months across 10 sites. 28 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: CN, A, P, S7, S.























Rare summer migrant. One of the last summer migrants to arrive, and one of the scarcest. First recorded on the 2nd of May at Out Head, with territories (mostly identified by singing birds) noted in at least ten different locations around town throughout summer. Also one of the earliest migrants to depart, with the final record for the year coming on the 17th of August at Out Head.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Bank Swallow
85 observations in 6 months across 13 sites. 270 total counted, high count 16. Breeding codes: N, H.























Common summer migrant. The least abundant of the three Hirundines to breed on the patch, but still a familiar sight around town, especially along the coast from Out Head to the Coastal Path; breeding was noted at both Out Head and The Scores. An early arriver on the patch, with the first record of the year on the 30th of March at North Haugh Pond; numbers built throughout spring to a high count of 16 birds at East Sands on the 11th of May. Fairly early to depart, with the final record this year on the 25th of August along The Scores.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Barn Swallow
272 observations in 7 months across 35 sites. 1082 total counted, high count 36. Breeding codes: FL, CN.























Common summer migrant. Abundant during summer throughout the patch, with records in all parts of town. First arrived on the 19th of April, when two birds were seen at the Aquarium. Bred locally, with nesting behaviour seen at East Sands on the 11th of May and young at the Aquarium on the 21st of July. Late to leave in the autumn, with the final record coming on the 13th of October, when four birds were seen at North Haugh Pond.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Western House-Martin
148 observations in 6 months across 31 sites. 2845 total counted, high count 232. Breeding codes: ON, H.























Common summer migrant. Regularly seen throughout town, and more prone to flocking than the other two Hirundines, with a peak count of 232 birds seen on the 8th of August at North Haugh Pond. First arrived on the 21st of April, when two birds were seen along the Coastal Path); the final record for the year was on the 30th of September, when 16 birds were seen by North Haugh Pond. Birds probably bred in several locations around the patch, but the only nests seen this year were around David Russell Apartments.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Willow Warbler
67 observations in 5 months across 11 sites. 123 total counted, high count 5. Breeding codes: FY, S7, S.























Common summer migrant. Although less abundant than Common Chiffchaff, with which it regularly co-occurred, nevertheless a common sight and sound around town during the breeding season, especially in the woods around the Balgove estate. Birds arrived on the patch in mid-April, with the first record on Watson Avenue on the 13th; the species remained present until the end of August, with a final record on the 26th of August at North Haugh Pond. Birds bred locally on the patch, with singing birds heard in many locations around town.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Chiffchaff
235 observations in 9 months across 26 sites. 495 total counted, high count 11. Breeding codes: CF, M, S7, S.























Common summer migrant. One of the most common songbirds during the summer months, being found all across town in trees and bushes. One of the first migrants to return, with the first record on the 8th of March at North Haugh Pond; similarly late to depart, with a final regular record on the 24th of October. Two records at North Haugh Pond in late December (and lingering into early 2025) probably referred to an overwintering individual. Birds bred locally on the patch, with singing birds heard in many locations around town and food carrying seen on two separate occasions along the Lade Braes.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Long-tailed Tit
168 observations in 12 months across 25 sites. 523 total counted, high count 18. Breeding codes: CN.























Common resident. A familiar sight throughout town, often seen in small family flocks numbering up to a dozen individuals, with their presence typically first betrayed by their high-pitched calls. The highest count for the year was of 18 birds (across two flocks) around North Haugh Pond on the 2nd of November. The only evidence of breeding on the patch was a bird carrying nesting material on John Knox Road on the 23rd of April.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Blackcap
83 observations in 9 months across 16 sites. 162 total counted, high count 5. Breeding codes: FL, S7, S.























Common summer migrant. Widespread throughout town during the summer months, more often heard than seen thanks to its distinctive song. The first record of the year was of an overwintering individual seen on Saint Leonard’s Road on the 13th of January; birds properly arrived on the patch in late March, with the first returning bird seen at North Haugh Pond on the 29th. The species bred on the patch, with singing birds heard in several locations and a recently fledged bird seen at North Haugh Pond on the 20th of July. Following breeding, birds began to depart through August and into autumn, with a final record for the year on the 10th of October at North Haugh Pond.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Greater Whitethroat
29 observations in 4 months across 13 sites. 45 total counted, high count 4. Breeding codes: CF, S7, S, H.























Uncommon summer migrant. A late arriver in the spring, with the first record on the 2nd of May (comprising two birds seen at the Out Head grass dump). Similarly early to leave in the autumn, with the final record for the year on the 26th of August at North Haugh Pond (likely a migrating bird, given this species’ absence around the pond during the summer). Birds bred in numerous locations around the patch, with most breeding records referring to singing birds but a couple of sightings of adults carrying food - one along West Sands on the 12th of July, and the other on Balone Steading on the 13th.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Goldcrest
178 observations in 12 months across 16 sites. 318 total counted, high count 10. Breeding codes: S7, S.























Common resident. Probably somewhat more widespread and abundant than records suggest, given the species’ unobtrusive nature and small size. Like Coal Tit, favours conifers woods around town, where it tends to remain high in the treetops, with its presence often only betrayed by its call or song. Probably bred locally, with singing birds heard in several locations around town during spring and summer.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Treecreeper
108 observations in 12 months across 15 sites. 130 total counted, high count 3. Breeding codes: S7, S.























Uncommon resident. Another relatively cryptic resident songbird, with its presence generally identified by its high-pitched call. Favours tall woodlands, and often seen as part of mixed feeding flocks comprising species such as Coal Tit and Goldcrest.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Wren
501 observations in 12 months across 40 sites. 1184 total counted, high count 16. Breeding codes: CF, FL, CN, C, S7, S.























Common resident. Abundant in all habitats throughout town, usually seen in small numbers but occasionally in little flocks or family groups; the highest count of the year was of 16 birds spread along the Lade Braes on the 15th of June. Bred locally, with singing birds heard in many locations around town and chicks seen on two occasions along the Lade Braes.

title: Species Accounts
text:
White-throated Dipper
23 observations in 9 months across 1 sites. 33 total counted, high count 4. Breeding codes: S.























Rare resident. Like Common Kingfisher, this species’ status on the patch is somewhat perplexing. Birds seemingly disappeared from their usual haunts along the Lade Braes during the summer months, before returning again in autumn, suggesting that they may breed elsewhere (perhaps further up the Kinness Burn)? Nevertheless, a reliable sight along the Burn in the cooler months of the year, with one or two birds usually present (and a high count of four birds seen on the 21st of January).

title: Species Accounts
text:
European Starling
376 observations in 12 months across 35 sites. 4053 total counted, high count 150. Breeding codes: NY, CF, S.























Common resident. Regularly seen all throughout the patch, particularly favouring the open habitat in the north of town, and the urban centre of town itself. Birds bred in several locations around the patch, with a nest seen on The Scores on the 19th of May, and birds carrying food seen at North Haugh Pond on the same day and near David Russell Apartments on the 24th of May. Often seen in large flocks in excess of 50 birds, with the highest count of the year being 150 birds at the Aquarium on the 10th of February during a storm.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Mistle Thrush
79 observations in 11 months across 17 sites. 194 total counted, high count 35. Breeding codes: A.























Common winter migrant. Although present on the patch in almost every month of the year, probably better described as a winter migrant given its scarcity during spring and summer. Seen in various locations around town throughout the winter, especially around North Haugh Pond. Most records were of single birds or small flocks, with the largest count by far being 35 birds at North Haugh Pond on the 24th of November, during a small fall of winter thrushes on the patch.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Song Thrush
119 observations in 11 months across 24 sites. 176 total counted, high count 7. Breeding codes: FL, M, S7, S.























Common resident. When singing, readily detectable (particularly given its tendency to sing from the tops of tall trees), but otherwise a relatively shy inhabitant of gardens and woodland around town. Bred in several locations around town, with recently fledged young seen at Out Head on the 26th of May and at North Haugh Pond on the 4th of June. Unlike the other thrushes, mostly seen in small numbers rather than flocks, with the highest count being of just seven birds (at Haugh Pond](site_accounts.qmd#north-haugh-pond) on the 11th of June).

title: Species Accounts
text:
Redwing
98 observations in 7 months across 20 sites. 923 total counted, high count 462. Breeding codes: none.























Common winter migrant. One of the most distinctive winter migrants on the patch, thanks to its high-pitched flight call and large flocks occasionally seen on migration. The final record for the spring came on the 3rd of April when two birds were seen at the Observatory; birds were not seen again until early October, with the first autumn record on the 9th at the same location. Although most counts were relatively low (usually less than ten birds), weather conditions on the morning of the 5th of November led to a count of 462 birds flying over the Aquarium over the course of an hour and a half.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Blackbird
530 observations in 12 months across 42 sites. 1466 total counted, high count 27. Breeding codes: CF, FL, T, M, S7, S.























Common resident. One of the most familiar birds throughout town, being resident in gardens as well as more natural habitat, and heard singing throughout the day during spring and summer. Numbers augmented during autumn and winter by birds from further afield; the highest count for the year was of 27 birds along the Lade Braes on the 23rd of November. Birds bred on the patch, with singing birds heard in many locations around town and a fledgling seen by Lade Braes on the 13th of July.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Fieldfare
9 observations in 4 months across 4 sites. 90 total counted, high count 67. Breeding codes: none.























Rare winter migrant. Distinctly less common than the other thrushes on the patch, with just a handful of records throughout the colder months of the year. Most records came from around North Haugh Pond, including the highest count of the year (67 birds on the 24th of November, the first record of the autumn).

title: Species Accounts
text:
European Robin
668 observations in 12 months across 45 sites. 1966 total counted, high count 24. Breeding codes: CF, FL, S7, S.























Common resident. As with Eurasian Blackbird, numbers on the patch bolstered in winter by the arrival of birds from further afield, but still very common throughout spring and summer. Bred on the patch, with fledglings seen in four different locations around town, and further breeding evidence and many other sites in addition.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Redstart
2 observations in 1 months across 1 sites. 2 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. One of the best birds of the year, with an adult male found in a garden on Watson Avenue on the 12th of April, probably a brief stopover on its migration north.

title: Species Accounts
text:
European Stonechat
38 observations in 12 months across 6 sites. 88 total counted, high count 6. Breeding codes: FL, P.























Uncommon resident. Mostly restricted to the scrubby habitat of the golf course and West Sands, with a handful of sightings elsewhere (including a couple on the field behind North Haugh Pond). Usually seen individually or in small family groups, with the highest count of the year comprising six birds on West Sands on the 21st of July. Birds bred locally, with fledglings observed in family groups between May and July on the golf course and along West Sands.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Northern Wheatear
2 observations in 2 months across 2 sites. 3 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: none.
