Rare passage visitor. Only seen twice this year, once in spring (two birds on the 6th of May at Out Head) and once in autumn (one bird on the 11th of August at North Haugh Pond). Probably more frequent on the patch than these records suggest, particularly at Out Head where there is extensive suitable passage habitat and birds were recorded on several other occasions throughout the year by other observers.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Bohemian Waxwing
1 observations in 1 months across 1 sites. 7 total counted, high count 7. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Despite the influx of birds into Britain in late 2023, by the start of 2024 only a relatively small number of birds remained in Fife, with just one flock seen in St Andrews this year - a small group of seven birds right on the edge of the patch near Balgove Bay on the 23rd of February.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Dunnock
421 observations in 12 months across 40 sites. 703 total counted, high count 10. Breeding codes: CF, S7, S.























Common resident. Ubiquitous throughout town in most habitats, easily detected by both its call and song despite typically skulking in dense vegetation. Usually seen in small numbers, with a high count of just 10 birds (along the Lade Braes on the 15th of June). Bred all across the patch, with adults seen carrying food in a couple of locations and birds heard singing in many more throughout spring and summer.

title: Species Accounts
text:
House Sparrow
337 observations in 12 months across 35 sites. 1979 total counted, high count 34. Breeding codes: CN, C.























Common resident. Found all across town, mostly around colonies with the odd record of a wandering bird elsewhere. At colonies, generally seen in flocks numbering in the dozens, with a high count of 34 birds (along the Lade Braes on the 15th of November). Surprisingly few breeding records, but seen carrying nesting material several times at East Sands during May, and no doubt bred successfully in the other colonies throughout the patch too.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Tree Sparrow
37 observations in 12 months across 7 sites. 166 total counted, high count 17. Breeding codes: FY, P, S.























Rare resident. Distinctly scarcer than House Sparrow, with only a handful of colonies around the patch, all in hedgerows on the outskirts of town. These colonies are also generally smaller in size than those of House Sparrow, with the highest count recorded in the year only 17 birds (on the 11th of August, in the colony between Swilken Burn and Balgove Bay).

title: Species Accounts
text:
Gray Wagtail
77 observations in 12 months across 16 sites. 89 total counted, high count 4. Breeding codes: FL, S.























Uncommon resident. Mostly restricted to aquatic habitats around town (particularly along the Lade Braes and by the coastline), but also often seen flying over, with its presence given away by its distinctive flight call and deeply undulating flight style. Birds bred locally on the patch, with a fledgling seen on Lade Braes on the 1st of August. Mostly seen individually, with a couple of records of multiple birds at a time and a high count of just four birds (at the Aquarium on the 7th of November).

title: Species Accounts
text:
White Wagtail
341 observations in 12 months across 27 sites. 1088 total counted, high count 62. Breeding codes: FL.























Common resident. Seen throughout the patch, being only really absent from the fields and farmlands south of town. Most common near the coast from Balgove Bay to Maiden Rock, especially along West Sands and around the Aquarium. Birds bred on the patch, with fledglings seen at several sites between May and July. Throughout most of the year generally seen in small numbers, but post-breeding flocks (likely involving birds from outside the patch as well) form in August and September, the largest this year comprising 62 birds seen near North Haugh Pond on the 16th of August. The vast majority of records of this species refer to the local British (Pied) yarrellii subspecies, but continental alba birds were seen at Out Head on the 21st of April.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Meadow Pipit
163 observations in 12 months across 20 sites. 417 total counted, high count 14. Breeding codes: CF, M, S7, S.























Common resident. Present throughout the year in open habitat across the patch, although less abundant (and probably less detectable) during winter. Birds bred throughout the patch, with singing birds heard in several locations and birds seen carrying food at North Haugh Pond, Out Head, and West Sands. Usually seen in small numbers, with occasional flocks of a dozen birds forming throughout the year, the largest comprising 14 birds at North Haugh Pond on the 21st of March.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Rock Pipit
87 observations in 11 months across 6 sites. 186 total counted, high count 9. Breeding codes: none.























Common winter migrant. Although present throughout almost all of the year, best described as a winter migrant to the patch given the disappearance of birds from their regular haunts along the coastline during spring and much of summer. Exclusively coastal, and mostly restricted to the rocky coastline from the Aquarium to East Sands. Not especially abundant, with the highest count of the year just 9 (by the Aquarium on the 1st of December).

title: Species Accounts
text:
Common Chaffinch
471 observations in 12 months across 38 sites. 1307 total counted, high count 18. Breeding codes: M, S7, S.























Common resident. One of the most common finches around town, seen in just about every habitat although most common in wooded habitats including parks and gardens. Birds bred locally, with singing birds heard all throughout the patch in spring and summer. Somewhat less prone to flocking than other finches, with the highest count recorded this year only 18 (comprising singing birds spread out along the Lade Braes on the 15th of June).

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Bullfinch
255 observations in 12 months across 25 sites. 526 total counted, high count 15. Breeding codes: FL, C, P.























Common resident. Often seen in small family flocks around town, especially around North Haugh Pond and along the Lade Braes. Bred locally, with fledglings seen in three locations across the patch between June and August. Never in large flocks, with the highest count just 15 birds (around North Haugh Pond on the 10th of February).

title: Species Accounts
text:
European Greenfinch
205 observations in 11 months across 32 sites. 363 total counted, high count 17. Breeding codes: S.























Common resident. Found throughout town, but especially common in open habitats including throughout the golf course and in the various fields and farmlands south of town. Generally seen in relatively small numbers, with the highest count this year being 17 birds in a flock near the Sports Centre on the 26th of October.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Linnet
187 observations in 12 months across 20 sites. 2063 total counted, high count 159. Breeding codes: FL, C, P, S7, S.























Common resident. One of the most abundant songbirds around town, especially during the warmer months of the year when seen throughout the patch especially in open habitats. Very prone to flocking, with several records of large flocks in excess of 50 birds throughout the year, including a flock of 159 at Out Head on the 15th of August.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Redpoll
3 observations in 2 months across 1 sites. 7 total counted, high count 5. Breeding codes: none.























Rare visitor. Probably prone to irruptions into the patch, but only recorded three times throughout the year, all at North Haugh Pond. All records were of Lesser Redpolls (subspecies cabaret), but other Redpoll taxa could well occur from time to time.

title: Species Accounts
text:
European Goldfinch
503 observations in 12 months across 42 sites. 2709 total counted, high count 78. Breeding codes: NY, C, S7, S.























Common resident. Probably the most abundant finch on the patch, being common all throughout town and often forming large flocks numbering in the dozens of birds. Bred in various locations around town, with the best breeding record being a nest with young found along the Coastal Path on the 19th of May. Often seen in flocks, with the largest of these being 78 birds at North Haugh Pond on the 3rd of October.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Eurasian Siskin
121 observations in 11 months across 15 sites. 343 total counted, high count 50. Breeding codes: S.























Uncommon visitor. Probably not permanently resident on the patch, but rather a regular visitor, with records in most months of the year but no definitive breeding evidence (and not regular at any one site throughout the spring and summer). Mostly restricted to parts of the patch with taller trees, particularly seed-bearing conifers. The largest flock of the year comprised 50 birds, seen flying over North Haugh Pond on the 12th of January.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Corn Bunting
2 observations in 2 months across 1 sites. 2 total counted, high count 1. Breeding codes: S7, S.























Rare summer migrant. Only a short range migrant, with birds presumably wintering somewhere in the East Neuk. This species’ presence on the patch this year marks a continuation of its’ expansion across eastern Fife, with territories recorded around St Andrews for the first time. My two records came from the fields by the A917, but a couple of other territories were mapped in other fields on the outskirts of town, with perhaps a total of half a dozen birds on the patch throughout the summer.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Yellowhammer
111 observations in 12 months across 19 sites. 299 total counted, high count 28. Breeding codes: S7, S.























Common resident. Present throughout the year in open habitats and hedgerows on the outskirts of town, including throughout the golf course. Bred throughout the patch, with singing birds heard in many locations between April and August. Usually seen in small numbers during the breeding season, but forms flocks in winter, with the largest of these being 28 birds in the fields south of town on the 25th of February.

title: Species Accounts
text:
Reed Bunting
35 observations in 11 months across 9 sites. 43 total counted, high count 2. Breeding codes: P, S, H.























Uncommon resident. Present throughout the year across the patch, but remarkably unreliable at any given location. Most records from around North Haugh Pond and along West Sands, but still not regularly seen at either site. Birds bred on the patch, with birds heard singing at several locations between May and July. Unlike Yellowhammer, not prone to flocking, with never more than two birds seen at once throughout the year.

localities <- read_sf("data/raw/pub_commcnc.shp")
patch_boundary <- localities %>% 
  filter(cc_name == "Royal Burgh of St Andrews") %>% 
  st_transform(crs = 4326) %>% 
  st_buffer(dist = 10)

ebird_raw <- read_csv("data/raw/MyEBirdData.csv")

rm(localities, ebird_raw, ebird_patch)


rollup_key <- ebird_taxonomy %>% 
  mutate(report_as = if_else(category == "species", species_code, report_as)) %>% 
  select(taxon_order, report_as) %>% 
  left_join(., 
            ebird_taxonomy %>% 
              select(-taxon_order),
            by = c("report_as" = "species_code"))

patch_observations <- read_csv("data/patch_observations.csv") %>% 
  select("checklist_id" = "Submission ID",
         "taxon_order" = "Taxonomic Order",
         "observation_count" = "Count",
         "locality_id" = "Location ID",
         "locality" = "Location",
         "latitude" = "Latitude",
         "longitude" = "Longitude",
         "observation_date" = "Date",
         "observation_time" = "Time",
         "protocol" = "Protocol",
         "duration_min" = "Duration (Min)",

         "effort_distance_km" = "Distance Traveled (km)",

patch_list <- patch_observations %>% 
  arrange(observation_date, observation_time, taxon_order) %>% 
  group_by(scientific_name) %>% 
  filter(row_number() == 1) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  mutate(obs_order = row_number()) %>% 
  arrange(taxon_order) %>% 
  mutate(tax_order = row_number()) %>% 
  arrange(observation_date, observation_time, taxon_order) %>% 
  select(obs_order, observation_date, locality, common_name, 
         scientific_name, tax_order, checklist_id) %>% 
  left_join(., ebird_taxonomy %>% 
              select(scientific_name, species_code), 
            by = "scientific_name") %>% 
  mutate(ebird_url = paste0("https://ebird.org/species/", 
                      species_code, "/GB-SCT-FIF"),
         link = str_replace_all(tolower(common_name), " ", "-"))

save(patch_list, file = "data/patch_list.RData")


patch_months <- reduce(
  list(
    patch_observations %>% 
      group_by(month = month(observation_date)) %>% 
      summarise(n_species = n_distinct(common_name)),
    patch_observations %>% 
      select(-c(taxon_order, observation_count, breeding_code, 
                report_as, scientific_name, common_name, order, family, 
                family_common, category, report_as.y, extinct)) %>% 
      distinct() %>% 
      filter(all_observations_reported == 1) %>% 
      group_by(month = month(observation_date)) %>% 
      summarise(n_completes = n_distinct(checklist_id)),
    patch_observations %>% 
      select(-c(taxon_order, observation_count, breeding_code, 
                report_as, scientific_name, common_name, order, family, 
                family_common, category, report_as.y, extinct)) %>% 
      distinct() %>% 
      group_by(month = month(observation_date)) %>% 
      summarise(n_days = n_distinct(observation_date),
                sum_duration = round(sum(duration_min, na.rm = TRUE)/60, 1),
                sum_distance = round(sum(effort_distance_km, na.rm = TRUE), 1)),
    patch_list %>% 
      group_by(month = month(observation_date)) %>% 
      summarise(n_additions = n_distinct(common_name))
  ),
  left_join
)

        "NY", "NE", "FS", "FY", "CF", "FL", "ON", "UN", "DD", "NB", "CN",
        "PE", "B", "A", "N", "C", "T", "P", "M", "S7", "S", "H"
      ))) %>%

patch_pulses <- list()

for (i in 1:nrow(patch_list)) {
  
  rrs <- filter(patch_monthrrs, common_name == pull(arrange(patch_list, tax_order), common_name)[i]) %>% 
    mutate(reporting_rate = if_else(reporting_rate > 1, 1, reporting_rate))
  
  patch_pulses[[i]] <- ggplot(rrs) +
    geom_rect(aes(xmin = month - 0.5, xmax = month + 0.5, ymin = -sqrt(reporting_rate), ymax = sqrt(reporting_rate))) +
    scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0.5, 12.5), expand = c(0, 0), breaks = 1:12, labels = str_sub(month.name, 1, 1)) +
    scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-1, 1), expand = c(0, 0)) +
    theme_nothing() +
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10)) +
    labs(x = NULL, y = NULL)
  
  rm(rrs)
}

title: About
text:
This website is a summary of my efforts to see as many birds as possible in St Andrews during 2024. All of my sightings were recorded on eBird.
This is a Quarto website.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.
To view the code for this website, see the GitHub repository at https://github.com/Louis-Backstrom/Patch-2024.

title: Month Accounts
text:
98 species (98 new) across 109 complete checklists. 38.5 total hours of effort across 31 patch days, covering 60.6 km.
A solid start to the year, despite recording less than 100 species throughout the month. The major highlights were my only records of Water Rail (by North Haugh Pond on the 6th), White-tailed Eagle (on Balgove Bay on the 13th), and Eurasian Woodcock (at North Haugh Pond on the 22nd). Other notable sightings included Common Snipe (by Balgove Bay on the 20th), Little Gull (off the Aquarium on the 6th), Little Grebe (off Maiden Rock on the 27th), European Shag (at the Aquarium on the 20th), Common Kingfisher (at Maiden Rock on the 27th), Common Raven (at North Haugh Pond on the 9th and 25th, the Observatory on the 11th, and by Lade Braes on the 27th), and an out-of-season Eurasian Blackcap (along Saint Leonards Road on the 13th).

title: Month Accounts
text:
98 species (98 new) across 109 complete checklists. 38.5 total hours of effort across 31 patch days, covering 60.6 km.
A solid start to the year, despite recording less than 100 species throughout the month. The major highlights were my only records of Water Rail (by North Haugh Pond on the 6th), White-tailed Eagle (on Balgove Bay on the 13th), and Eurasian Woodcock (at North Haugh Pond on the 22nd). Other notable sightings included Common Snipe (by Balgove Bay on the 20th), Little Gull (off the Aquarium on the 6th), Little Grebe (off Maiden Rock on the 27th), European Shag (at the Aquarium on the 20th), Common Kingfisher (at Maiden Rock on the 27th), Common Raven (at North Haugh Pond on the 9th and 25th, the Observatory on the 11th, and by Lade Braes on the 27th), and an out-of-season Eurasian Blackcap (along Saint Leonards Road on the 13th).

title: Month Accounts
text:
February
101 species (9 new) across 118 complete checklists. 44.1 total hours of effort across 29 patch days, covering 83.6 km.
A slightly better month than January in terms of species tally, but somewhat diminished in terms of quality. The standout bird of the month was my only record of Bohemian Waxwing (a flock of 7 twitched between Swilken Burn and Balgove Bay on the 23rd). Other notable sightings included my first of three Redpoll sightings for the year (5 birds at North Haugh Pond on the 6th), Common Raven continuing at North Haugh Pond (on the 6th, 8th, 10th, and 18th) for a couple of weeks before disappearing, a Little Gull at the Aquarium on the 9th in the middle of a storm, and the first returns of two (primarily) summer migrants to the patch: Lesser Black-backed Gull (first at the Aquarium on the 17th) and Northern Gannet (first off the Aquarium on the 29th).

title: Month Accounts
text:
March
98 species (5 new) across 108 complete checklists. 42 total hours of effort across 31 patch days, covering 81.9 km.
A quiet month, with less than 100 species recorded and few sightings of any great note (every species recorded in March was also recorded in at least one other month). Highlights included my only record of Whooper Swan for the first half of the year (4 birds off the Aquarium on the 3rd), first records of Short-eared Owl (at Out Head on the 30th) and Tawny Owl (at home on the 30th), last records (for the first winter period) of Velvet Scoter (at the Aquarium on the 17th) and Common Greenshank (by the Coastal Path on the 23rd), and the first returns of a handful of summer migrants to the patch, all at North Haugh Pond: Common Chiffchaff (first on the 8th), Eurasian Blackcap (29th), and Bank Swallow (30th).

title: Month Accounts
text:
April
97 species (8 new) across 93 complete checklists. 35.6 total hours of effort across 25 patch days, covering 58.7 km.
A below-average month in terms of species observed (partially owing to time spent off-patch in the Highlands), but with a number of highlights. The two standouts were my only records of Black-tailed Godwit (a flock of 11 at Balgove Bay on the 6th) and Common Redstart (twitched on Watson Avenue on the 12th) for the year. Other notable sightings included the first of a number of Common Loon sightings for the year (off the Aquarium on the 21st), the last records of a number of winter migrants: Pink-footed Goose (at North Haugh Pond on the 11th), Northern Pintail (at Balgove Bay on the 21st), Greater Scaup (at Out Head on the 22nd), Black-bellied Plover (at Balgove Bay on the 21st), Common Redshank (at Balgove Bay on the 21st), Horned Grebe (at Balgove Bay on the 21st), Great Crested Grebe (at Balgove Bay on the 21st), and Redwing (at the Observatory on the 3rd), and first records for several summer migrants: Sandwich Tern (at East Sands on the 13th), Barn Swallow (at the Aquarium on the 19th), Western House-Martin (on the Coastal Path on the 21st), and Willow Warbler (on Watson Avenue on the 12th).

title: Month Accounts
text:
May
98 species (8 new) across 100 complete checklists. 43.4 total hours of effort across 29 patch days, covering 74.4 km.
An exciting month with plenty of migratory and breeding activity, but ultimately little payoff in patch listing terms, with less than 100 species recorded and none unique to the month. Highlights included the first Corn Bunting territory in St Andrews in modern times (my first observation in the fields south-east of town on the 25th), my only spring records of Northern Wheatear (at Out Head on the 6th) and Barnacle Goose (at Balgove Bay on the 19th), the last records of a handful of late-departing winter migrants: Eurasian Wigeon (at Balgove Bay on the 19th), Long-tailed Duck (at Out Head on the 19th), Ruddy Turnstone (at the Aquarium on the 5th), Red Knot (at Balgove Bay on the 4th), Sanderling (at Out Head on the 6th), and Purple Sandpiper (at Out Head on the 6th), and the arrival of a few late-returning summer migrants: Common Swift (at North Haugh Pond on the 10th), Osprey (at Out Head on the 6th), Sedge Warbler (at Out Head on the 2nd), and Greater Whitethroat (at Out Head on the 2nd).

title: Month Accounts
text:
June
91 species (4 new) across 79 complete checklists. 32.8 total hours of effort across 21 patch days, covering 59.7 km.
One of the quietest months of the year, with the lowest tally and no unique species, although total effort was reduced owing to a trip to Switzerland in the latter half of the month. Highlights included out-of-season records of Brant (2 at Balgove Bay on the 17th), Canada Goose (18 over North Haugh Pond on the 5th), and Eurasian Jay (2 in Lumbo Den on the 1st), as well as the first record of Arctic Tern for the year (off the Aquarium on the 18th), and the arrival of a pair of Eurasian Coot at North Haugh Pond (first seen on the 3rd) that remained throughout the summer and ultimately bred.

title: Month Accounts
text:
July
100 species (4 new) across 96 complete checklists. 42.1 total hours of effort across 26 patch days, covering 63.2 km.
A solid month with a reasonable tally and some quality sightings, although once again no unique species. Total effort slightly reduced once again due to a trip to Wales in the middle of the month. The undeniable star of the month was a Lesser Yellowlegs found on the 24th down by The Scores (twitched by me later that evening); this was only the second Fife record of the species, and the bird showed well on the rocks around Castle Sands for more than a week. Other highlights included Common Sandpiper (also on the rocks by The Scores during the same period, first seen on the 23rd), the first Parasitic Jaeger for the autumn (off the Aquarium on the 28th), a handful of Little Gull sightings (off the Aquarium on the 9th, The Scores on the 10th, and a flock of 9 at Out Head on the 21st), the first Manx Shearwater for the autumn (off The Scores on the 5th), and what turned out to be my last record of European Shag for the year (at the Aquarium on the 25th).

title: Month Accounts
text:
August
103 species (2 new) across 109 complete checklists. 48.3 total hours of effort across 26 patch days, covering 74.8 km.
One of the best months of the year, with a high tally and a number of good species seen. The best find of the month was a Red Phalarope down on Balgove Bay late in the evening of the 27th, an unusual record both due to its timing (very early in the autumn) and location (in the estuary, rather than offshore). Other highlights included the Lesser Yellowlegs and Common Sandpiper continuing down by The Scores at the start of the month, the passage of Canada Goose (first seen on the 13th at home) and Whimbrel (first seen on the 1st at Out Head) through the patch, the (rather late) arrival of Common Tern (off the Aquarium on the 11th), a Short-eared Owl lingering around the Eden Estuary (first seen at Out Head on the 1st), and my only autumn record of Northern Wheatear (at North Haugh Pond on the 11th).

title: Month Accounts
text:
September
92 species (2 new) across 20 complete checklists. 11.7 total hours of effort across 6 patch days, covering 15.1 km.
A quiet month, but mostly due to being off-patch in Australia for all but the last week or so; this may well have been one of the best months of the year if I’d been around for more of it. The major highlights of the month were a Sooty Shearwater off The Scores on the 26th, and a juvenile Ruff on Balgove Bay in the morning of the 28th. Other highlights included the arrival of a number of winter waterfowl: Pink-footed Goose (over North Haugh Pond on the 24th), Barnacle Goose (over the Aquarium on the 26th), Eurasian Wigeon (down at Balgove Bay on the 28th), Northern Pintail (also at Balgove Bay on the 28th), Greater Scaup (Balgove Bay on the 28th), Long-tailed Duck (Balgove Bay on the 29th), and Horned Grebe (Balgove Bay on the 29th), and the departure of a couple of summer migrants: Common Tern (last seen off The Scores on the 26th) and Western House-Martin (at North Haugh Pond on the 30th).

title: Month Accounts
text:
October
109 species (2 new) across 93 complete checklists. 43.8 total hours of effort across 31 patch days, covering 64.9 km.
A very good month, with the highest species tally for the year and a number of good birds found. The major highlight was my only Great Skua for the year, flying past the Aquarium on the 1st. Other highlights included my first of two Western Barn Owl records, this one a fortuitous sighting on the evening of the 23rd at the start of the Strathkinness Low Road, and the return of Eurasian Jay to North Haugh Pond (first seen on the 4th, with several records throughout the month). Winter migrants continued to arrive, with Whooper Swan at Balgove Bay on the 13th, Velvet Scoter off the Aquarium on the 8th, Purple Sandpiper by the Aquarium on the 9th, Great Crested Grebe off the Aquarium on the 8th, and Redwing at the Observatory on the 9th. Similarly, the last summer migrants disappeared throughout the month, with Eurasian Coot last at North Haugh Pond on the 3rd, Barn Swallow similarly last at North Haugh Pond on the 13th, and Eurasian Blackcap at North Haugh Pond on the 10th.

title: Month Accounts
text:
November
108 species (4 new) across 71 complete checklists. 33.2 total hours of effort across 30 patch days, covering 51.5 km.
Perhaps the best month of the year, and almost entirely due to a number of great birds seen off the Aquarium at various points throughout the month. The first of two major highlights was an Iceland Gull off the Aquarium on the 4th, found late in the evening in fading light and not relocated on subsequent visits. The second highlight was a distant Red-necked Grebe twitched off the Aquarium on the 26th (in rather better light, thankfully); on the same day I picked up my first Atlantic Puffin for the year, part of an influx into the patch that continued through December. Other highlights included a handful of Dovekie (also off the Aquarium, with the first bird on the 16th), a late Sandwich Tern (off the Aquarium on the 7th), a number of Common Loon sightings (off both the Aquarium and The Scores), a family of Tawny Owl by home on the 14th, a Common Raven pair down by the Aquarium on the 5th, my first Fieldfare for the second winter period (a flock of 67 at North Haugh Pond on the 24th), and my second and third Redpoll sightings for the year (singles at North Haugh Pond on the 4th and 15th).

title: Month Accounts
text:
December
102 species (1 new) across 80 complete checklists. 38.4 total hours of effort across 31 patch days, covering 61 km.
A fairly subdued end to the year, with a reasonable species tally but only a handful of noteworthy sightings. The major highlight of the month was a Black Guillemot off the Aquarium on the 20th, completing the set of all 5 regular British auk species on the patch, and being my final addition to the year list. Other highlights included an unusual Tufted Duck sighting (at Balgove Bay on the 14th), a Common Snipe at North Haugh Pond (on the 8th), five Atlantic Puffin in St Andrews Bay (singles off the Aquarium on the 14th and 23rd, and 3 together off The Scores on the 14th), a final Dovekie sighting (off the Aquarium on the 21st), a Western Barn Owl near North Haugh Pond on Christmas night, and an out-of-season Common Chiffchaff that hung around North Haugh Pond for a couple of days at the end of the month (first found on the 20th).
